en.sc1: Consider a list $L$ containing seven records, named $r_1$ through $r_7$.
en.sc2: The records could be complex, with many fields. But assume that each record includes a particular field that we will call the key. In this example, the associated keys are 3 1 7 6 4 7 0.
en.sc3: The Sorting Problem is to arrange the records into any order $s$ such that records $r_{s_1}$, $r_{s_2}$, ..., $r_{s_n}$ have keys obeying the property $k_{s_1} \leq k_{s_2} \leq ... \leq k_{s_n}$. In other words, the sorting problem is to arrange a set of records so that the values of their key fields are in non-decreasing order.
en.sc4: Define $L_S$ to be a sorted version of $L$. The records in $L_S$ are arranged so that the keys are in non-decreasing order. Records $r_3$ and $r_6$ could have appeared in either order since their key values are the same.
